Posts.Content: I was 4 wks post op and thought a morning of fishing would be perfect. So Monday morning I stopped at my local fast food giant and ordered a sausage muffin. 4 hrs later a case of the "screamers" hit and I couldn't get home quick enough. That progressed into 36 hrs of dry heaves every 30 min. I wanted to die. I finally got some food and Gatorade held down Wednesday night but still feel very weak and swear a truck ran over me. I guess I just didn't realized how run down your body gets after major surgery.
Posts.Signature: psa: 0.8 from '08 to '10, 2.7 ('11), 4.2 ('12), 4.4 ('13 & '14), 7.7 (4/2015) DRE: normal , father PC 12 core biopsy (6/2/15) adenocarcinoma 4 of 12 cores pos: #1..GS6 (3+3) 5%, #2..GS6 (3+3) 15%, #3..GS6 (3+3) 5%, #4..GS7 (3+4) 40% no perineural invasion ID 7/24/15 RALP @ UWM Madison, Wi 7/28/15 Post op path report upgraded to: G 4+4 = 8/10 w/ some tertiary pat 5 present, and approx 20% involved. Extracapsular extension, invasion into muscle wall, bladder base, peripheral margins, all lymph nodes are negative. Small amount of perineutral invasion noted. Final staging classified as pT2c. Both nerve bundles spared and long bladder neck retained. 10/9/15 First post-op PSA test..zero! 2/8/16 Second post-op test..zero! 5/23/16 Third post-op test..zero! 8/15/16 Fourth post-op test..zero!

Posts.Title: Thought I was doing great!

Posts.Content: Checked back w/ the doctor's office today and no biopsy report back after 1 full week. His nurse told me that she'd check every day and bump me into his schedule as soon as it comes back. I'm following several forum suggestions and ordered Walsh's book. I looked over the John Hopkins site for 2nd opinions, got real familiar w/ my insurance benefits and coverage, and made additional copies of my medical records. Then, I got mad at myself for getting all worked up over something I can't control, and went fishing for the day. I think fishing cures just about everything! LOL

Posts.Title: One year anniversary....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter Where is the pain? If it is near the incision sites it should go away soon? If not near the incision sites and you also have other symptoms like a fever you need to consult your surgeon. One thing few surgeons talk about post op is the possibility of lymphedema and lymphocele. Do you have leg swelling post surgery and is the pain near the lower abdomen? Lymphocele is a collection of lymphatic fluid in the lower abdominal cavity. Usually it is asymptomatic and goes away after a short period but if it gets infected it can cause pain in that area. You had a successful surgery and lets hope it is just a case of simple recovery. Good luck. Since I first posted, it's become much better. All 6 sites have healed. There has been no fever and only minor swelling of the testicles. The "pain" is best described as....my insides are trying to re-position themselves after sitting upright for any length of time....if that makes any sense! Still working on the kegels and incontinence but overall, life is good! I feel very blessed with the outcome.

Posts.Title: Abdominal pain?

Posts.Content: All of my 6 incisions have finally healed over and quit leaking. The last 2 nights I was able to sleep a bit on my side instead of my back...what a relief! I'm still having some sharp pains if I sit any length of time, bend the wrong way, or make any sudden moves. I suppose it's normal after everything was moved and poked during the surgery. How long does this last? A couple of Tylenol in the AM and PM seem to help.

Posts.Title: Abdominal pain?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter No one commented so let me try. First of all, congrats for an excellent surgical outcome with all negative margins and cancer confined to your prostate. As far as I know, some surgeons do practice the technique you described, and mine was one of them. Good luck. My surgeon was Dr. Hedican at UWM. He was a chief resident at Johns Hopkins under Dr. Walsh. I'm going to ask a few more questions at my first post op appointment tomorrow. He did mention the length of the bladder neck would help on the time returning to continence.

Posts.Title: Path report today?

Posts.Content: I received a very welcome call from my surgeon this morning. The path report bumped my previous scores to several G7's and a few G8's. A couple of the G8's had 5's. But, all margins were clear, all lymph nodes were clear, he spared both nerve bundles, and told me he had a rather long bladder neck for connection. He told me that the later would aid incontinence issues much quicker. I don't recall coming across this anywhere else. Has anyone else heard this?

Posts.Title: Path report today?

Posts.Content: Over the last few years I've had a couple of stricture issues that required surgical procedures and resulting catheter use. That's when I first learned that some folks are allergic to Neosporin type products. I was told that it's due to the "sulpha" contained in this and similar products. I now use Aquaphor for any type of irritated skin. It seems to run in our family. My brother developed a rash after using Neosporin following skin cancer removal. When I told him about my reaction and he brought it to his dermatologist attention. She had him switch and he cleared right up.

Posts.Content: Thanks to everyone on the forum. I went in armed w/ a boatload of information which was VERY helpful when the doctor gave me my "certificate" to become an official club member. We discussed some options and I'll be meeting w/ the surgeon in the near future. He's Dr. Fumo, the head of the robotics program here in Rockford w/ over 1000 procedures under his belt. I'm still planning to have a 2nd opinion from the team at UWM in Madison.

Posts.Title: The waiting period is over.

Posts.Content: I'm 15 days post-op and had the same bladder spasms for the first 2 days. My doctor ordered the same Rx w/ 5mg taken every 8 hrs. They cautioned me not to take it any sooner than 8hrs. It does cause some rather nasty dry mouth but sure was worth the relief. Don't hesitate to call anytime if you have problems. That's why they give you the number! After the first BM and a few room clearing farts, things really did start improving. Wishing you the very best!

Posts.Title: Any suggestions for bladder spasms?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Hi Gary, The Gleason 3+3 is a low risk type of prostate cancer and there is an old saying that "No man ever dies from Gleason 3+3." YOu also have Gleason 7, which is happily a 3+4 instead of a 4+3. This is a moderatly aggressive type of PC, but the 3+4 often acts very much like 3+3. So whether you choose one of the two primary treatment types (radiation or surgery), you should have an excellent chance for a complete cure. Your low PSA of 1.9 further suggests this. As long as it is confined to the prostate -- and it probably is -- the tumor volume is not as important. Of course, with radiation you would want it to be as small as possible to have less tumor to treat. With surgery, the baby goes out with the bathwater -- prostate, tumors and all -- no matter their size -- all come out. You might want to read a gold standard PC book by Dr Pat Walsh called the "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer." Make sure it's the 3rd edition. And stand by as others jump in to give you more information & comments. All in all, I'm sure you are going to be just fine. Chuck I just spotted the part about "3'rd edition". Still waiting on delivery of my "2'nd edition". What's the major change?

Posts.Title: Tumor volume and treatment

Posts.Content: I've been leaning toward robotic surgery for the last month but still wanted to keep an open mind on brachytherapy. I finally made the choice to have robotic surgery at UWM (Madison, Wi) with Dr Sean Hedican due to some other stricture issues. I learned today that he was trained by Dr Patrick Walsh at Johns Hopkins. He still does a few open procedures but now favors the robot for almost everything. I came in armed w/ two pages of questions. He spent over 40 minutes answering every one in great detail. Then, before I left, he asked if there was anything else he could answer. Even though I have to travel to Wisconsin, I feel very comfortable with the facility and the doctor. I've already had very favorable interactions w/ his staff this afternoon. I can't thank this forum enough for all the valuable information that helped me make my choice. I almost feel relief knowing I'm another step closer to getting this cured.

Posts.Content: Has anyone used the facilities at UWM in Madison? Are there any recommended doctors in their urology department? I'm getting my biopsy results back sometime next week and plan to have the results (positive or negative) examined there for a second opinion. I've been using that facility for several years to treat my wife's problems and have been quite impressed with the team approach from this teaching hospital.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by shu246 G19 - I felt a lot more at ease after understanding that the procedure, altho serious surgery, is VERY commonly done - prostate cancer being high on the list of male cancers and - if found early and confined within the prostate - effectively and confidently dealt with. Best wishes. Tell us when you have your date for the dance. - Shu July 24th @ 7:30A and the catheter gets removed on July 31st @ 10:30A.....had a choice of 10:30 or 11:30 on this one. Picked 10:30A ...'cuz it's SOONER! LOL

Posts.Title: Made my choice today

Posts.Content: I'm 9 days post op from RALP. 5 of the 6 openings are healing nicely. They used a lot of glue and strips. However, the top incision (think it's the one used for the CO2) keeps opening and leaking fluid. That was the one opening that didn't show any residual glue or tape. There is still quite a bit of swelling behind that point. I mentioned it at my post op visit and was told everything was healing nicely. It almost looks like a hernia has developed at that point. I say this because I had a hernia repaired w/ mesh about 15 years ago and that's very close to the bottom edge of the mesh. Just wondering if anyone else has experience this kind of leakage and what outcome did you have.

Posts.Title: Question on wound care & healing?

Posts.Content: I'm the same 3 days post op. The first two were really tough w/ severe gas pains and bladder spasms. Today was MUCH better. A hot shower, clean clothes, lots of walks, and eating regular food are my new high points. That's right after the best part of the day....a room clearing fart! LOL I can't say enough about UWM (Madison) doctors and entire staff for my treatment. These folks are fantastic.

Posts.Title: Post RP

Posts.Content: Like previously mentioned, many folks are allergic to Neosporin....myself included. Whenever I change pads, I use Aloe Vesta cleansing foam to clean and then Aloe Vesta daily moisturizer. both were provided by UWM (Madison) when I was discharged.

Posts.Title: Need help- rash from pads

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ray61 My center one, the one nearest the belly button, looked nasty for a few weeks after the others healed. After 9 days there is still a lot of swelling and pressure that can cause some drainage which should be clear and not smell. Shouldn't last too much longer though. Ray Yup...that's pretty much what it is. Just when I think it's done leaking, it leaks again for a short time and then quits. It's related to how much I've been sitting around or just being active. Guess I'll just be careful and hope it heals soon. Thanks for the replies.

Posts.Title: Question on wound care & healing?

Posts.Content: I'm on 2.5 mg/day of Cialis for post op ED rehab. I was able to get a 30 day supply of the 5 mg strength w/ the free voucher. No problem splitting each one for a 2 mo supply. Of course, my insurance denied coverage on the initial request and appeal from the doctor. I've had a favorable experience with another Rx a couple of years ago via a pharmacy in Canada. Cialis by brand name is only half the cost and the generic version (not available in the US) Tadalafil is less than a fourth the cost. Has anyone gone this route and what has been your own experience?

Posts.Title: Cialis sources?

PatientDecided.Sample: I finally made the choice to have robotic surgery at UWM (Madison, Wi) with Dr Sean Hedican due to some other stricture issues. I learned today that he was trained by Dr Patrick Walsh at Johns Hopkins....I've been leaning toward robotic surgery for the last month but still wanted to keep an open mind on brachytherapy. I finally made the choice to have robotic surgery at UWM (Madison, Wi) with Dr Sean Hedican due to some other stricture issues....
